thread.title: Nejapa residents celebrate volcanic eruption in fireball festival (VIDEO)
thread.title_full: Nejapa residents celebrate volcanic eruption in fireball festival (VIDEO)

title: Nejapa residents celebrate volcanic eruption in fireball festival (VIDEO)
text:
Nejapa residents celebrate volcanic eruption in fireball festival (VIDEO) Wednesday September 2, 2015 Print Article 
NEJAPA, Sept 2 — It may look like gang warfare but it’s actually a joyous annual celebration. 
The young men and women of Nejapa near San Salvador, are marking the anniversary of a volcanic eruption in 1922 that forced residents to abandon the town. 
The eruption of a volcano in El Salvador nearly a hundred years ago has spawned a bizarre but spectacular tradition in the small town of Nejapa. — Reuters pic And they do it by soaking rags in gasoline, setting them on fire and throwing them at one another. 
Dangerous? perhaps... but it’s an event the entire town, including the church, looks forward to every year. 
Urban legend says that the lava that flowed from the volcano was in fact, a local Saint called Jeronimo fighting the devil with balls of fire. 
There are other versions of the story, although for participants, all that seems to matter is that a flaming good time — without injuries — is had by all. — Reuters More Stories for You:
